report_title: Industry Report on Physical Therapy Rehabilitation Centers
executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency.

For most of the past decade, physical therapy rehabilitation centers in the US have enjoyed revenue growth as a result of an aging population since seniors aged 65 years and older are more likely to require physical therapy services as they face a higher incidence of injuries, illnesses and chronic conditions. Consumers have increasingly accepted the benefits of physical therapy services, supporting demand for the industry. However, in 2020, revenue dropped as the COVID-19 pandemic kept patients in their homes and away from inpatient facilities. The release of pent-up demand has brought back revenue growth, but inflationary pressures have muted the industry's rebound as consumers delay minor treatments not covered by their insurance plans. Industry revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 0.8% to $46.9 billion up to the end of 2023 when revenue will climb by 3.5%.

Despite the economy struggling during the period, the industry remains profitable because physical therapy centers derive a large share of revenue from Medicare reimbursements. At the same time, diminished Medicare reimbursement rates have reduced the average income received per patient, dragging down profit. Although relatively steady demand has buoyed profit, a labor shortage across much of the healthcare sector has increased the wages of physical therapy rehabilitation centers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In the years leading up to the pandemic, the aging population, rising levels of healthcare expenditure, broader insurance coverage and broader healthcare trends all supported demand for physical therapy rehabilitation centers. COVID-19 disrupted these trends, though. The pandemic swiftly cut the accessibility and affordability of physical therapy treatment, forcing rehabilitation centers to endure a sharp drop in revenue. Unlike private practices, rehabilitation centers saw a slow recovery in 2021 as restrictions on inpatient care made it difficult to treat long-term care patients. Patient volumes have finally recovered from the pandemic's challenges in 2023. Despite fears of a recession and lingering pressure from inflation, the unavoidable nature of injuries and illnesses provides rehabilitation centers with steady demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rehabilitation Centers Create Opportunities for Collaboration
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As more focus has been given to value-based healthcare, collaborative medicine has become increasingly important. If a patient needs multiple types of therapy, a physical therapy rehabilitation center is well-suited to provide those services. Many rehabilitation centers have also joined healthcare networks as the sector has moved toward consolidation. These networks can provide collaborative care by easily sharing records and referrals, reducing the burden on physical therapy (PT) clinics.

Before COVID-19, 98.0% of physical therapists didn't provide video consultations, according to the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) report. By September 2020, 75.0% of physical therapists were using telehealth. Regulatory constraints are limiting physical therapists' telehealth adoption in 2023, though. The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) final ruling affirmed PT privileges ended 151 days after the end of the public health emergency.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Employment Grows Despite Physical Therapist Shortage
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Because of the high cost of education and a growing need for medical services that has brought heightened burnout for physical therapists, there has been an increasing shortage of potential employees in the industry. According to Definitive Healthcare, 22,000 physical therapists left the workforce in 2021 amid this burnout. Combined with the retirement of seasoned physical therapists, clinics have struggled to fill their workforces. These shortages are most acute in rural areas, where patients already experience barriers to care. Physical therapy rehabilitation centers have had better luck finding physical therapists since working in a rehabilitation facility offers more stability than private practice. Even with the added stability, rehabilitation facilities must offer competitive salaries to continue to attract skilled physical therapists. These rising wage expenditures have dragged down profit for the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demographic Trends Are Driving Growth for Physical Therapists
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Because of the high prevalence of musculoskeletal (MSK) conditions among older adults, an aging population is driving the increasing demand for physical therapy. As more consumers age into the oldest age bracket, the biggest source of demand for the industry's services climbs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Healthcare Trends Call for a Change in Physical Therapy Services Moving Forward
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Physical therapy rehabilitation centers will continue to see an uptick in demand as the population ages. Adults 65 and older have the highest incidence of musculoskeletal conditions. An aging population's rising consumption of healthcare services contributes to higher healthcare costs. Physical therapy can present a solution to growing costs through a first-line treatment approach.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Physical Therapists Will Be the First Stop
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A new, cost-saving approach to services for physical therapy will prompt patients to visit a physical therapy clinic to manage initial symptoms, avoiding costly visits to an ER, hospital or primary care physician. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend rehabilitation plans, including physical therapy, to treat patients suffering from post-COVID-19 conditions. How growing research unfolds regarding long-term COVID-19 symptoms will determine physical therapy's role in treatment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation Will Continue to Integrate the Industry With the Broader Sector
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large private practices and healthcare investors have consistently sought to purchase rehabilitation centers to reduce costs through economies of scale. These acquisitions also boost their market share. While the initial investment to offer inpatient facilities can be significant, inpatient facilities can exert more substantial buying power and have greater access to high-value patients. As Medicare reimbursement rates continue to slump and operating costs grow for physical therapist practices, consolidation and investment will likely drive more businesses into the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Labor Shortages Threaten Long Term Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While rehabilitation centers have been relatively shielded from the growing physical therapist shortage, the industry won't be entirely immune to staffing limitations in the coming years. Across the healthcare sector, healthcare providers are facing a shortage of nurses, technicians and other medical staff. The high cost of education, limited wages and a surplus of healthcare job openings discourage potential physical therapists from taking up the trade. Rehabilitation centers must increase wages to maintain steady growth and avoid employee burnout. As a relatively profitable part of the healthcare sector, rehabilitation centers are well-positioned to offer competitive wages to.

industry_definition: Physical therapy rehabilitation centers are facilities that provide therapy and training for rehabilitation. Industry establishments include freestanding rehabilitation hospitals, acute care hospitals with inpatient rehabilitation centers and outpatient rehabilitation centers that provide physical, occupational or speech therapy services. This report excludes drug, alcohol and other rehabilitation services.

opportunities: Number of adults aged 65 and older

key_trends: The aging population has supported revenue growth. A higher incidence of musculoskeletal ailments among older adults is boosting demand for ongoing physical therapy.
High operating costs have driven consolidation. Physical therapists have sought to share resources and join rehabilitation facilities for stability.
Medicare funding determines the success of rehabilitation centers. Many patients rely on Medicare for long-term treatment, providing a steady revenue stream.
Certificate of Need laws limit competition. However, they can also make it difficult for rehabilitation centers to expand in saturated areas.

Orthopedic care provides the greatest share of revenue. Patients with severe physical injuries will quite often need long-term orthopedic care, providing a stable source of revenue for physical therapists.
Government insurance payments provide consistent revenue. Medicare often covers at least a portion of long-term physical therapy
Physical therapy practices favor metros. Densely populated metropolitan areas give physical therapy practices access to a more extensive patient base.
Alternative medicine can challenge physical therapy. Alternative medicine is less costly than physical therapy in non-emergency situations, boosting competitive pressures.
Reputation and therapist rapport are vital to maintaining patient relationships. If patients need ongoing care, they will likely seek out a highly recommended physical therapist.
No rehabilitation centers hold a substantial market share. Despite several companies having a national presence, the industry has a significant focus on local and regional care.
Cost pressures constrain profit growth. The recovering patient volumes post-COVID-19 hasn't been enough to offset the rising input costs and wage expenditures PT clinics are facing.
Persistent labor shortages pressure wages to rise. Physical therapy clinics are paying higher salaries to attract and retain qualified staff.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Reimbursements from private payors include payments received from commercial health plans. Physical therapy is an essential health benefit, so nearly all private insurers must cover PT. Still, the type and extent of coverage can vary by plan.

Government revenue sources include reimbursements from Medicaid and Medicare and grants or loans from federal or state agencies. Medicare sets annual limits on the amount of PT it will cover (the limit changes annually). Modifications to these caps influence how much revenue physical therapy clinics receive from public payors.

Other sources of revenue also include contributions and payments for non-patient care to healthcare practitioners (incentive payments, management fees and medical director fees) and payments from workers' compensation, property and auto insurance providers.
Revenue sources include reimbursements from the Medicaid program.
Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients or family members for any care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance.

products_and_services.product_description: Orthopedic physical therapists diagnose, manage and treat musculoskeletal disorders and injuries, including rehabilitation after orthopedic surgery.
Orthopedic care treats many conditions, severe injuries are more likely to require long-term orthopedic rehabilitation.
A speech therapist is a specialist with training in diagnosing and treating various speech, voice and language disorders.
Pediatric physical therapists assist in the early detection of health problems and use a wide variety of modalities to treat disorders in children.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Device Manufacturing in the US
Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Medical Supplies Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Health & Medical Insurance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Physical Injuries Fuel the Need for Orthopedic Rehabilitation
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Orthopedic physical therapists diagnose, manage and treat musculoskeletal disorders and injuries, including rehabilitation after orthopedic surgery. Orthopedic rehabilitation is the largest source of revenue for physical therapy rehabilitation centers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Speech Pathology Helps Patients Regain Quality Of Life
demand_determinants.determinant_description: A speech therapist is a specialist with training in diagnosing and treating various speech, voice and language disorders. Patients may also seek speech pathology care if they have a stutter or other speaking impediment.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Pediatric Physical Therapy Is The Start Of A Lifetime Of Care
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Pediatric physical therapists assist in the early detection of health problems and use a wide variety of modalities to treat disorders in children.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As the country's largest population hub, this area has the most rehabilitation centers to address the medical needs of its population.

Florida is home to the most physical therapy rehabilitation centers in the Southeast. Florida's high average age drives demand for physical therapists in the state. Adults 65 and older have the highest incidence of musculoskeletal conditions, making a robust medical infrastructure essential to the needs of the population.
The Mid-Atlantic's share of clinics mirrors its share of the nation's population. Pennsylvania and New York contribute substantially to the share of establishments in this region.

New York's high population density influences the number of physical therapy (PT) clinics in the state. New York has the third-most physical therapists in the entire US. New York City also has more residents than those in North Dakota, Wyoming, and Alabama combined, warranting a greater need for more physical therapy facilities. PT clinics in New York City benefit from concentrated demand that allows them to treat a high number of patients.
The West's share of PT clinics falls closely in line with its share of the US population. The high concentration of clinics in the region is primarily a result of population distribution.
California has the highest number of clinics in this region and the entire US. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, California has the most practicing physical therapists in the country.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Anti-Kickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits exchanging anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) for the referral of any business reimbursable by federal healthcare programs (Medicare, Medicaid). Kickbacks promote overutilization of healthcare, create higher costs and corrupt patients' decision-making. Physical self-referral laws prohibit physicians from referring patients to a healthcare service if they or a family member have a financial relationship with that entity.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services pays participating physical therapy practices under its Medicare and Medicaid programs based on various formulas. Federal law mandates services rendered to Medicare and Medicaid patients meet professionally recognized standards. CMS provisions also ensure that healthcare services are medically necessary and reimbursement claims are filed correctly.

Physical therapy practices must prove a Certificate of Need (CON) before any construction, renovation or major medical equipment acquisitions. CONs are state regulatory mechanisms for healthcare facilities that determine the public need for a new facility or services. CON oversight ensures health delivery services align with community needs to prevent heightened healthcare costs. Violations of CON requirements can result in civil sanctions or revocation of a facility's license.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Physical therapy practices must follow the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) criteria. HIPAA outlines controls for patient health data for any healthcare provider that stores, shares, or sends private patient data, no matter the size of the practice. These rules are designed to ensure the privacy and security of patient records and prevent unauthorized disclosure.

basis_points.basis_description: Alternative medicine can challenge physical therapy. Alternative medicine is less costly than physical therapy in non-emergency situations, boosting competitive pressures.
Reputation and therapist rapport are vital to maintaining patient relationships. If patients need ongoing care, they will likely seek out a highly recommended physical therapist.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: A Shortage in Physical Therapists is Driving Wage Growth
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A brutal labor shortage has made it very expensive for physical therapy rehabilitation centers to maintain a staff of qualified medical professionals, pushing wage expenditures upwards faster than revenue growth can accommodate.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: RISING RENT AND PROPERTY COSTS CHALLENGE HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Property values in many cities have been rising, making it challenging to develop state-of-the-art physical therapy rehabilitation centers without significant capital.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Practices rely on a staff of qualified physical therapists, PT assistants and nonclinical employees. Since technology can't substitute labor, new clinics must contend with rising wages, employee burnout and staffing shortages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Physical Therapy is More Discretionary Than Other Medical Services
volatility_points.volatility_description: Physical therapy (PT) services are more discretionary than other medical treatments, making this industry more sensitive to insurance coverage and economic factors that influence employment and changes in income.

Physical therapy can't be substituted in severe cases where patients may need to relearn motor skills like walking. Still, available substitutes create volatility when appropriate since patients can opt for lower-cost services as their spending power drops.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers?
FAQs.answer: Rehabilitation centers enable physical therapists to share resources and reduce costs.

FAQs.question: Has increased access to health insurance offered opportunities for your company?
FAQs.answer: As funding for Medicare has grown, demand for physical therapy has also increased.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage visits from individuals who lack health insurance?
FAQs.answer: A significant number of patients have coverage through Medicare or Medicaid.

FAQs.question: Is your company geographically positioned in communities where there is a strong need?
FAQs.answer: Rehabilitation centers are mainly located in highly populated areas.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in new technology to improve internal processes?
FAQs.answer: Rehabilitation clinics have been able to reduce costs through automation and online record keeping.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored offering telehealth services to improve patient accessibility and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Telehealth has not been an option for most physical therapists due to the physical nature of the service.

FAQs.question: Have your regulatory expenses been impacted by federal healthcare reform?
FAQs.answer: Federal reimbursement for physical therapy has steadily increased over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: All physical therapists must be certified and have significant training.

FAQs.question: How do you keep operating costs down while still providing high levels of service?
FAQs.answer: Rehabilitation centers are a way for physical therapists to provide better service at a lower cost.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company have to replace its equipment?
FAQs.answer: Physical therapists must replace their equipment frequently to maintain high quality service.

FAQs.question: How have you dealt with negative effects of government policies? Do you discuss with clients how such policies can affect them?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be sure to comply with regulation or risk fines or the loss of revenue streams from government insurance such as Medicare.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? Does your staff undergo constant training?
FAQs.answer: A highly skilled workforce is crucial in the industry, as employees are heavily relied on to provide personalized services.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Have you had any problems with reliability in the past?
FAQs.answer: Those with strong reputations will receive more referrals, leading to more patients and revenue.

FAQs.question: How many of your patients pay for services through Medicare and Medicaid? How can you appeal to more Medicare and Medicaid recipients?
FAQs.answer: Federal and state funding of Medicare and Medicaid and the terms of access to these reimbursement programs affect demand for physical and related therapy services.

FAQs.question: How many of your patents have private health insurance? How can you expand the portfolio of insurance types you accept?
FAQs.answer: Trends in per capita disposable income growth influences the number of people who purchase private health insurance.

FAQs.question: Do you offer services tailored to the senior population?
Do your employees specialize in ailments specific to this demographic?
Number of adults aged 65 and older
FAQs.answer: As people age, their need for medical care rises dramatically, especially concerning inpatient rehabilitative therapy services.
